answers: Venus figurines [accept Venuses or Venus of Willendorf, Hohle Fels, etc.]
Austria [accepte Österreich]
caves <JM, Ancient/Archaeology>
parts: Give this figure that names all those objects, the oldest of which was made from mammoth ivory in Hohle Fels (“HO-luh FELSE”). Another object named for this figure is distinguished by its large belly and acorn-like hairstyle.
The most famous Venus figurine was found in this country’s town of Willendorf (“VILL-en-dorf”). The proto-Celtic Hallstatt (“HALL-shtott”) culture is named for an archaeological site in this country.
The Venus of Hohle Fels was found in one of these places. Paintings of bulls are frequently found on the walls of these places, which include Lascaux (“lass-KO”) and Altamira.

answers: superoxide [or O2 minus; accept superoxide dismutase; do not accept or prompt on “O2”]
hydrogen peroxide [or H2O2]
horseradish [accept Armoracia rusticana or Cochlearia armoracia] <RN, Biology: Genetics/Cell>
parts: Name this reactive radical ion. Mutations in another enzyme that dismutates this ion have been shown to cause Lou Gehrig’s disease.
Superoxide dismutase converts superoxide into this other molecule, which can itself decompose into two hydroxyl radicals. Catalase converts this molecule to water.
A peroxidase from this plant is used as a reporter enzyme in Western blots and ELISA (“ee-LIE-zuh”) assays. That enzyme from this plant turns TMB blue.

answers: The Flowers of Evil [or Les fleurs du mal]
Charles Baudelaire

corpses [or cadavers or dead bodies or carcasses or charognes or morts; accept dead people; accept “A Carcass” or “Une charogne” or “The Joyous Corpse” or “Le mort joyeux”; prompt on bodies] <WA, Poetry>
parts: Name this poetry collection whose entry “The Litanies of Satan” repeatedly implores the title figure to “take pity on my long misery!”
This decadent 19th-century French poet wrote The Flowers of Evil.

A disturbing poem from The Flowers of Evil that sexualizes one of these objects describes watching it “blossom like a flower” in the summer while “black battalions” of creatures emerge from it. The speaker wishes to “sleep in oblivion like a shark” in a Baudelaire sonnet titled for a “joyous” one of these.

answers: Tintoretto [or Jacopo Comin]
Bacchus AND Ariadne [accept Dionysus in place of “Bacchus”] (The other artist is Titian.)
The Last Supper <WA, Painting/Sculpture>
parts: Name this Venetian artist whose cycle about the patron saint of his city, Saint Mark, includes his paintings Saint Mark’s Body Brought to Venice and The Miracle of the Slave.

Tintoretto’s depiction of Venus and these two figures is widely regarded as a reference to Venice’s traditional “wedding to the sea” ceremony. In another Venetian artist’s painting titled for these two figures, a pair of cheetahs look out at the sea on the left and snakes strangle a man on the right.
Tintoretto’s less Venetian-themed works include two depictions of this scene, one of which oddly uses a diagonal angle for the central table. Leonardo’s version of this scene shows Judas whispering.

answers: evolutionary psychology [or evo psych; prompt on psychology or evolution]
Steven Pinker
The Origin of Species [or On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life] <WA, Social Science: Psych>
parts: Name this field. Its founders included the husband-and-wife team John Tooby and Leda Cosmides (“KOZ-mid-eez”), who expounded a critique of the “standard social science model,” or SSSM, in their book The Adapted Mind.
This Harvard psychologist and linguist criticized the title concept from the SSSM in The Blank Slate. This author’s books for a popular audience include The Language Instinct.
Evolutionary psychology is ultimately rooted in this book by Charles Darwin, in which he propounded the theory of evolution by natural selection.

answers: work
virtual [accept virtual work or virtual particles]
Rudolf Clausius <WA, Physics>
parts: Name this quantity that can be calculated as the spatial path integral of force, or sometimes more simply as “force times distance.”
D’Alembert (“dal-om-BAIR”) developed a principle named for this type of work. This adjective also describes instantaneously created particles whose lifetime is limited by the uncertainty principle.

Joule introduced the idea of mechanical work in 1845, around the same time as this German physicist developed the ideas put forth in “On the Moving Force of Heat.” A later paper by this scientist introduced the concept of entropy.

answers: blue sky [or blue skies; accept blue sky research; prompt on sky]
Tim Berners-Lee [or TimBL]
FDA [or Food and Drug Administration] <WA, Other Academic>
parts: Give this two-word phrase that, in science, refers to basic research that is conducted without taking into account any practical application.

One major product of blue sky research was this British computer scientist’s research into communications for CERN, which led to the creation of hypertext. As a result, he is credited with inventing the World Wide Web.

About 80 percent of medicines approved by this US federal agency can be traced back to basic research, although it takes on average 31 years from when the research was conducted until this agency’s approval.

answers: Nathaniel Hawthorne
staff [or walking stick or cane]
Herman Melville <AR, Short Fiction>
parts: Name this author who collected “Rappaccini’s Daughter” and “Young Goodman Brown” in Mosses from an Old Manse.

Early on, Young Goodman Brown meets an elderly man holding this creepy, snake-like object. After finding Faith’s pink ribbon, Goodman Brown uses this object to run extremely fast to the story’s concluding Satanic ritual.

This author called “Young Goodman Brown” as “deep as Dante” and not-so-subtly described how Hawthorne “dropped germinous seeds into [his] soul” in his review of Mosses from an Old Manse titled “Hawthorne and his Mosses.” He wrote The Piazza Tales.

answers: Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus [accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, Wittgenstein’s Tractatus or answers that indicate the Tractatus of Ludwig Wittgenstein; prompt on Tractatus]
Ludwig Wittgenstein
elementary propositions <WA, Phil/Thought>
parts: Name this work of analytic philosophy structured around seven major propositions. Many of its ideas were rejected in its author’s later major work, Philosophical Investigations.
The Tractatus and Philosophical Investigations are both by this Austrian-born philosopher and laid the foundations for much analytic philosophy.
According to the Tractatus, all complex propositions are truth-functions of these simpler sorts of propositions. Wittgenstein calls one of these propositions a “nexus” or “concatenation of names.”

answers: Steve McQueen
Lars von Trier (The films are Nymphomaniac and The House that Jack Built.)
Martin Scorsese (“scor-SAY-zee”) [or Martin Charles Scorsese] <RK, Other Arts: Film>
parts: Michael Fassbender played the sex addict Brandon, whose life is thrown out of balance by his sister’s return, in this British director’s film Shame. This man directed 12 Years a Slave.

In a lengthy erotic film by this director, Seligman’s accounts of fly-fishing parallel the sexual experiences of Joe, who is played by Charlotte Gainsbourg. The 2018 premiere of a film by this director about a serial killer led to several mass walkouts at Cannes (“can”).
Paul Schrader, who fictionalized the life of sex addict Bob Crane in his 2002 film Auto Focus, is better known for writing screenplays for films by this director, such as Taxi Driver and Raging Bull.

answers: general welfare clause
Alexander Hamilton
Tenth Amendment <WA, US History>
parts: Name this clause from Article I, Section 8 of the US Constitution which states that Congress may tax and spend for debts, common defense, and for this clause’s namesake purpose.
A broad interpretation of the general welfare clause was put forth by this Founding Father, who claimed that it granted Congress plenary power to spend. He was the first US Secretary of the Treasury.

Opponents of the broad interpretation of the general welfare clause often cite this constitutional amendment, which concerns “powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution.” The Helvering ruling held that Social Security did not violate this amendment.

answers: non-vascular plants
rhizoids [do not accept or prompt on “rhizomes”]
seeds <RR, Biology: Dev/Plant>
parts: Some of the earliest types of plants fall into this category, named for the lack of tracheary (“TRAY-kee-airy”) elements or other types of tissue to conduct water. They include bryophytes, liverworts, and hornworts.
Without vascular tissue, more ancient plants also lack proper root systems and instead use these root-like structures.
Modern plants produce these reproductive structures. Spermatophytes are plants that bear these structures containing the embryo, nutrients, and protection within a coat.

answers: Philippines [or Republic of the Philippines; or Republika ng Pilipinas]
Catholicism [or Catholic Church; prompt on Christianity]
magical realism [or magic realism; or marvelous realism; or realismo mágico; or lo real maravilloso] (The unnamed novel is Isabel Allende’s The House of the Spirits.) <JM, Misc Lit>
parts: Name this country. A novelist and ophthalmologist called this country a “lost Eden” in a poem that he wrote while awaiting his execution titled “My Last Farewell.”

That author, José Rizal, reacted to the abuse by Spanish priests of this religion in novels like Noli Me Tángere (“no-lee may TAHN-gay-ray”). Two Portuguese missionaries of this religion travel to Japan in Shūsaku Endō’s Silence.

Nick Joaquin, the author of A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, contributed to this style with stories like “May Day Eve.” Alejo Carpentier’s (“ah-LAY-ho car-pen-tee-AIR’s”) preface to The Kingdom of This World coined the term for this style, which was used for a novel set at the hacienda Las Tres Marías.

answers: Jules Ferry [accept Jules Ferry laws]

Treaty of Versailles <ML, European History>
parts: Name this leader who annexed Tunisia, Madagascar, North Vietnam, and Congo for France. He is more famous for a law that fully secularized the French education system.
This other French prime minister was a leading opponent of Ferry’s colonial policy. He was nicknamed “The Tiger,” and his magazine L’Aurore (“lo-ROR”) published Émile Zola’s J’Accuse.
Georges Clemenceau was the French representative of the “Big Four” during negotiations of this treaty. This treaty ended World War I.

Thule [accept Thule Society or Thule-Gesellschaft] <WA, Myths/Legends>
parts: Name these letters used by Vikings and other early Germanic peoples, some of whom also believed that they could be used to cast spells.
In the Poetic Edda, this god appears under his name of Ríg (“reeg”) and teaches runes to his son Jarl (“yarl”). This Norse god has golden hair, golden teeth, a golden horse, and a golden horn.

The study of runic magic was revived in the 20th century by an occultist organization named for this place that advocated Ariosophy and, unsurprisingly, was full of Nazi sympathizers. This mythical land of the far north is described in Latin and Greek literature.

parts: Name these two empires, one of which annexed the regions of Karabagh, Imeretia, and Shirvan from the other. These two empires signed the Treaty of Gulistan.
Heraclius II ruled this kingdom as part of its long-serving Bagrationi (“ba-gra-tee-OWN-ee”) royal house. This kingdom’s earlier rulers included David the Builder and Queen Tamar.

William Morgan Shuster, a banker from this country who was appointed as Persia’s finance minister, attacked Anglo-Russian influence in his book The Strangling of Persia. This country would later have its citizens abducted during a 1979 hostage crisis in Iran.

parts: Name this four-part series translated from Italian by Ann Goldstein. Its first entry begins with the disappearance of the protagonist’s “brilliant friend,” Lila Cerullo.

A major antagonizing force throughout Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan Novels is the Solara family, who head one of these organizations. Mario Puzo’s novel The Godfather centers on one of these organizations.

The pseudonymous Elena Ferrante was outed as translator Anita Raja in Claudio Gatti’s article printed in a magazine based in this city. That “Review of Books” based in this city publishes a celebrated line of “Classics.”

answers: Peter Grimes
Benjamin Britten
mystery plays [or miracle plays; prompt on plays or drama; do not accept or prompt on “mummer’s plays” or “morality plays”] <WA, Classical/Opera>
parts: Name this opera in which the death of the apprentice John at sea is represented by an eerie tuba solo. At its end, the title sailor is implied to have died by sinking his own ship, which Auntie dismisses as “one of these rumors.”
Peter Grimes is an opera by this British composer of A Young Person’s Guide to the Orchestra.

Britten’s opera Noye’s Fludde (“noise flood”), meant to be performed by young people and amateurs, is adapted from a cycle of these performances that originated in Chester. These performances were accompanied by antiphonal (“an-TIFF-uh-null”) song, and many of them were created in the 16th century by the Wakefield Master.

answers: river basin [or drainage basin or catchment basin; or watershed; or catchment area; or impluvium; prompt on drainage area]
ephemeral streams [prompt on arroyos or wadis]
GIS [or geographic information systems; accept ArcGIS; prompt on databases or information systems] <WA, Earth Science>
parts: Give this term for the entire area drained by a river. These areas may be endorheic (“en-doh-REE-ick”) if they do not drain to an ocean.

Some of the most marginal components of a river basin are streams denoted by this adjective, which only flow briefly after rainfall. These sorts of streams are contrasted with perennial streams, which always flow, and intermittent streams, which flow for a few months of the year.

The flows of ephemeral streams are tracked using data stored in these systems, which collect, analyze, and display data about various spaces on the Earth. Esri developed the “Arc” example of these systems.

Ignatius of Loyola founded this religious order whose members conducted extensive missionary and education work in Asia and the Americas. Pope Francis is the first Pope from this order.

This other 16th-century Spanish clergyman wrote the treatise Ascent of Mount Carmel, which instructs people how to achieve mystical union with Christ and begins with his poem “Dark Night of the Soul.”
